Description.val:
The LCS Mine Countermeasures (MCM) Mission Package (MP) counters bottom, tethered, near surface, and surface mines in the littorals without putting Sailors in the minefield. When the MCM MP is embarked, LCS is capable of conducting detect-to-engage operations (hunting, sweeping, and neutralization) against shallow and deep-water sea mine threats. The MCM MP provides these capabilities through the use of sensors and weapons deployed from an embarked MH-60S multi-mission helicopter and unmanned offboard vehicles. The embarked MH-60S employs the Organic Airborne Mine Countermeasures systems to provide rapid minehunting. 

Organic Airborne Mine Countermeasures (OAMCM) systems provide the long-range, airborne capability to conduct minehunting and clearing operations in littoral zones, confined straits, choke points, and the Amphibious Operations Area (AOA) quickly.

The Coastal Mine Reconnaissance Module will detect mines in the surface zone and beach zone areas, providing the Joint Force Commander with the information needed to clear mines with non-LCS assets and allow military forces to safely and effectively storm the beaches.  This procurement line supports the LCS mine countermeasures mission package, providing deployable combat capability to the LCS MCM squadron. 

The Airborne Mine Neutralization Module (MH-60S Helo + Airborne Mine Neutralization System) and Near Surface Detection (NSD) Module (MH-60S Helo + Airborne Laser Mine Detection System) achieved Initial Operational Capability (IOC) in Q1 FY 2017.  

The program will add future capabilities to provide a surface influence sweep capability via the Unmanned Minesweeping (UMS) Module: Unmanned Surface Vehicle and Minesweeping Payload Delivery System (previously known as Unmanned Influence Sweeping System (UISS)) for high-speed influence minesweeping, Remote Minehunting Module (Unmanned Surface Vehicle and Minehunting Payload Delivery System) to detect bottom and tethered mines and the Buried Minehunting Module (Knifefish Unmanned Underwater Vehicle) to detect buried mines and mines in a high clutter environment. When complete, the MCM MP will provide full capability against floating, tethered, bottom, and buried mines.

The MCM MP is deployable and capable of meeting its focused mission requirements on an LCS only when it includes the full complement of Common Mission Modules Equipment (Line Item Number 1600) and the full complement of mission systems that comprise each MCM Module (Line Item Number 1601). 

Other Related Budgets: BLIs: OPN 1600, OPN 1602, OPN 1603, OPN 4248, OPN 2622, OPN 2624, WPN 4221, WPN 4225, RDT&E 0603596N

[P5 / Minesweeping Payload Delivery System]: Beginning in FY 2020, the program is aligning the budget to reflect the planned procurement strategy of the Unmanned Surface Vehicle (USV) that is part of both the Unmanned Minesweeping Module and the Remote Minehunting Module.  As such, the budget breaks out the procurement of the vehicles, the Payload Delivery System (PDS), and associated payloads.

Justification.val:
FY 2020 funding includes the procurement of two Unmanned Minesweeping Modules, four Remote Minehunting Modules, two Buried Minehunting Modules, three additional Minehunting Payload Delivery Systems to back-fit Unmanned Minesweeping Modules with Remote Minehunting capability, one Airborne Laser Mine Detection System (ALMDS), one Coastal Battlefield Reconnaissance and Analysis (COBRA) system, two AN/AQS-20Cs and associated MCM MP support equipment. All MCM assets procured in FY 2020 support MCM MP deployments starting in FY 2022.  The increase in FY 2020 from FY 2019 is attributed to ramping production following mission system testing and following the initial procurement of the Buried Minehunting Module (two Knifefish systems and ancillary equipment) as well as the Remote Minehunting Module.

The FY 2020 funding request was reduced by $1.000 million to account for the availability of prior year execution balances.

Remarks.val:
[Hardware] MC001- The Unmanned Minesweeping Module provides an unmanned surface, long endurance bottom sweep capability to clear large areas of mines that may remain after mine-hunting operations are complete.

[Hardware] The Buried Minehunting Module provides capability to detect and identify buried mines and mines in a cluttered ocean bottom environment.  This procurement line supports the LCS mine countermeasures mission package, providing deployable combat capability to the LCS MCM squadron.

[Hardware] MC006 - MCM SUPPORT EQUIPMENT]: Support equipment related to the individual modules.

[Hardware] The Remote Minehunting Module consists of an Unmanned Surface Vehicle and a Minehunting Payload Delivery System for deploying and retrieving the AN/AQS-20 minehunting sonar. Beginning in FY 2020 the USV is common between the Unmanned Minesweeping Module and the Remote Minehunting Module. The USV is capable of supporting both minehunting and minesweeping missions. FY 2020 procurements will be competitively sought. Pricing in FY 2020 reflect production startup plus competitive procurement pricing.  The LCS MM Program requires a total of 48 Unmanned Surface Vehicles and 48 Minehunting Payload Delivery Systems to support minehunting missions.

[Support Cost] MC900 - Provides program management support, engineering and technical support, studies, analysis and evaluation on mission module systems.

Name.@footnote: The Unmanned Minesweeping Module consists of an Unmanned Surface Vehicle (USV) and a Minesweeping Payload Delivery System (PDS).  Prior to FY 2020, this system was known as the 1.1.1) Unmanned Influenced Sweep System (UISS).  The LCS MM Program requires a total of 24 Unmanned Minesweeping Modules.
Name.val: 1.1.2) Unmanned Surface Vehicle for UMS Module

Name.@footnote: The Minesweeping Payload Delivery System (PDS) plus the Unmanned Surface Vehicle (USV) form the Unmanned Influence Sweep System (UISS).  The Minesweeping PDS includes the MK-104 payload.

Name.val: MC003 - ORGANIC AIRBORNE MINE COUNTERMEASURES (OAMCM) SYSTEMS

Name.@footnote: AMNS unit pricing reflects contract actuals.
ALMDS unit prices are based on economic order quantity / step-ladder pricing in existing contract.

2.1.4) AMNS Tech Refreshes improve reliability and maintainability to previously procured AMNS units and correct deficiencies that allow the equipment to perform in accordance with current deployment configuration / operational requirements.
Name.val: 2.1.3) AMNS Technology Refresh and Obsolescence Upgrades
2.1.4) ALMDS Technology Refresh and obsolescence Upgrades

Name.@footnote: FY17 - FY20 reflects Economic Order Quantity (EOQ) when taking into consideration the COBRA training assets procured through OPN Line Item 2624 where COBRA systems are procured to provide initial and proficiency training to Navy aircrews.

The FY 2019 Knifefish pricing is based on the current EDM/LRIP contract and reflects procurement of two (2) Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUVs). FY 2020 through FY 2024 pricing is based on a planned competitive contract and is based on the Program Lifecycle Cost Estimate (PLCCE).  The LCS MM Program requires a total of 24 Knifefish systems.

The unit cost includes all necessary equipment to outfit the Buried Minehunting (BMH) Module to include the base pallet, launch and recovery device, shipping containers, support equipment (Deck tie down case, ballast transport case, grapple assembly, winch case, and other tools), and the BMH Specialized Container.

Beginning in FY 2020, the program is aligning the budget to reflect the planned procurement strategy for the Unmanned Surface Vehicle (USV) that is part of both the Unmanned Minesweeping Module and the Remote Minehunting Module. Prior to FY 2020, this Cost Element (6.1.1 - MCM USV) reflects the procurement of one vehicle and one Minehunting Payload Delivery System (PDS).  Beginning in FY 2020, the budget breaks out the USV and the Minehunting PDS into seperate Cost Elements, 6.1.2 and 6.1.3 respectively.

The Unmanned Surface Vehicle (USV), Minehunting Payload Delivery System (PDS), and the AN/AQS-20 minehunting sonar form the Remote Minehunting (RMH) Module.  The LCS MM Program requires a total of 24 RMH Modules.

The LCS MM Program requires a total of 48 Minehunting Payload Delivery Systems (PDS) to enable the 48 USVs procured for both the Unmanned Mine Sweeping (UMS) and the Remote Minehunting (RMH) Modules to perform minehunting missions.  Cost Element 6.1.4 procures the 24 Minehunting PDS required to backfit the 24 USVs in the UMS Modules (procured in cost element 1.1.2 - Unmanned Surface Vehicle) allowing those assets to support both mine sweeping and minehunting missions.
Name.val: 6.1.4) Minehunting Payload Delivery System (to backfit UMS Module USV)

Name.@footnote: The AQS-20C is a towed variable depth minehunting sonar.  FY 2020 unit cost reflects Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) for production line startup costs associated with competitively awarded contract.
